title: How to Prune Tea Roses

steps.headline: Trim off the upper branches.
steps.description: Start off by getting your rose bush down to about 14 inches (36 cm) tall using pruning shears. Clip off the tops of the bush, trimming it enough so that you can clearly see the bottom of the stems and which way they’re growing. Pruning the plant lower will help promote new shoots. Cut the stems at approximately a 45° angle to prevent you from having to go back and re-cut your branches later in the process.

steps.headline: Cut off dead or diseased growth.
steps.description: Use the pruning shears to remove stems that are brown, shriveled up, or diseased. If the plant is diseased, you might see a hole in the stem once it’s cut, or a brown center. Keep cutting this off until you get to a healthy white core. Remove all of the old foliage as well. After you've removed the damaged part, cut about 1–2 centimetres (0.39–0.79 in) off of the stem at a time until you reach a white core.

steps.headline: Remove stems that are crossing one another.
steps.description: If you see branches that are criss-crossing each other, remove the branch that’s reaching inwards. Removing these will keep them from rubbing up against each other and getting tangled.

steps.headline: Take off branches that are super thin or weak.
steps.description: Your goal is to keep stems that are strong and thick, so remove ones that seem too thin to support the weight of the plant. The branch should be at least as thick as a pencil, as well as green and healthy. If you have lots of branches that seem healthy and strong, aim for clipping off the thinner ones until you have 5-6 main stems.

steps.headline: Cut each branch at a 45° angle.
steps.description: When using your pruning shears, instead of creating a flat cut right across the stem, aim for making an angled cut. This allows water to drain off more easily, preventing water from collecting and causing rot. A 45° cut also helps prevent pests from sitting on the stems.

steps.headline: Trim stems growing into the center to allow better air flow.
steps.description: Opening up the center of the plant will let more air and sunlight filter through, benefiting the rest of the plant. If you see branches that are growing inwards instead of outwards, cut these off. If the entire branch is growing inwards starting at the base near the roots, cut the entire branch off.

steps.headline: Remove buds that are facing the interior of the plant.
steps.description: If you see a bud forming that’s facing the middle of the plant instead of growing outwards, clip this off. You want buds that will grow away from the plant, or even ones that are facing to the side. Be careful to only clip off the small bud, not the entire stem.

steps.headline: Prune right above an outward-facing bud to encourage the growth.
steps.description: After you’ve spotted a bud that’s growing out and away from the plant, prune right above the bud. Clipping too close to the bud might damage it, so aim for cutting roughly 0.25 in (0.64 cm) above the bud. Pruning this way will encourage your blooms and branches to grow outward, instead of toward the center of the plant. Don’t forget to cut at an angle with your pruning shears.

steps.headline: Prune the tea roses in the winter or spring, depending on your climate.
steps.description: If you live in a climate that gets warmer towards the end of the winter, you can prune the tea roses then. If you live somewhere with cold, longer winters, you'll need to wait until spring. Once the threat of frost passes, you're ready to prune.

steps.headline: Clean your pruning shears using soap and water.
steps.description: Pour a dab or two of dish soap onto a sponge or washcloth. Run the sponge or washcloth under warm water and begin scrubbing down the pruning shears. Once they're all clean, run them under water to rinse the soap off and dry them thoroughly. Cleaning your pruning shears (or scissors, if necessary) is important so that you don't spread disease while cutting stems. Drying your shears super well right after washing them will help prevent rust.

steps.headline: Apply wood glue to the stem after you make a cut.
steps.description: This helps seal off the cut, preventing disease and insects from getting into the plant and eating it. You can use a regular wood glue that's water soluble. Find wood glue from a home improvement or art store. You can also purchase specialty glues that are designed specifically for pruning roses.

text: Removing Unwanted Stems Trim off the upper branches. Start off by getting your rose bush down to about 14 inches (36 cm) tall using pruning shears. Clip off the tops of the bush, trimming it enough so that you can clearly see the bottom of the stems and which way they’re growing. Pruning the plant lower will help promote new shoots. Cut the stems at approximately a 45° angle to prevent you from having to go back and re-cut your branches later in the process. Cut off dead or diseased growth. Use the pruning shears to remove stems that are brown, shriveled up, or diseased. If the plant is diseased, you might see a hole in the stem once it’s cut, or a brown center. Keep cutting this off until you get to a healthy white core. Remove all of the old foliage as well. After you've removed the damaged part, cut about 1–2 centimetres (0.39–0.79 in) off of the stem at a time until you reach a white core. Remove stems that are crossing one another. If you see branches that are criss-crossing each other, remove the branch that’s reaching inwards. Removing these will keep them from rubbing up against each other and getting tangled. Take off branches that are super thin or weak. Your goal is to keep stems that are strong and thick, so remove ones that seem too thin to support the weight of the plant. The branch should be at least as thick as a pencil, as well as green and healthy. If you have lots of branches that seem healthy and strong, aim for clipping off the thinner ones until you have 5-6 main stems. Directing the Growth Cut each branch at a 45° angle. When using your pruning shears, instead of creating a flat cut right across the stem, aim for making an angled cut. This allows water to drain off more easily, preventing water from collecting and causing rot. A 45° cut also helps prevent pests from sitting on the stems. Trim stems growing into the center to allow better air flow. Opening up the center of the plant will let more air and sunlight filter through, benefiting the rest of the plant. If you see branches that are growing inwards instead of outwards, cut these off. If the entire branch is growing inwards starting at the base near the roots, cut the entire branch off. Remove buds that are facing the interior of the plant. If you see a bud forming that’s facing the middle of the plant instead of growing outwards, clip this off. You want buds that will grow away from the plant, or even ones that are facing to the side. Be careful to only clip off the small bud, not the entire stem. Prune right above an outward-facing bud to encourage the growth. After you’ve spotted a bud that’s growing out and away from the plant, prune right above the bud. Clipping too close to the bud might damage it, so aim for cutting roughly 0.25 in (0.64 cm) above the bud. Pruning this way will encourage your blooms and branches to grow outward, instead of toward the center of the plant. Don’t forget to cut at an angle with your pruning shears. Choosing Best Practices Prune the tea roses in the winter or spring, depending on your climate. If you live in a climate that gets warmer towards the end of the winter, you can prune the tea roses then. If you live somewhere with cold, longer winters, you'll need to wait until spring. Once the threat of frost passes, you're ready to prune. Clean your pruning shears using soap and water. Pour a dab or two of dish soap onto a sponge or washcloth. Run the sponge or washcloth under warm water and begin scrubbing down the pruning shears. Once they're all clean, run them under water to rinse the soap off and dry them thoroughly. Cleaning your pruning shears (or scissors, if necessary) is important so that you don't spread disease while cutting stems. Drying your shears super well right after washing them will help prevent rust. Apply wood glue to the stem after you make a cut. This helps seal off the cut, preventing disease and insects from getting into the plant and eating it. You can use a regular wood glue that's water soluble. Find wood glue from a home improvement or art store. You can also purchase specialty glues that are designed specifically for pruning roses.
sentences: Removing Unwanted Stems Trim off the upper branches.
Start off by getting your rose bush down to about 14 inches (36 cm) tall using pruning shears.
Clip off the tops of the bush, trimming it enough so that you can clearly see the bottom of the stems and which way they’re growing.
Pruning the plant lower will help promote new shoots.
Cut the stems at approximately a 45° angle to prevent you from having to go back and re-cut your branches later in the process.
Cut off dead or diseased growth.
Use the pruning shears to remove stems that are brown, shriveled up, or diseased.
If the plant is diseased, you might see a hole in the stem once it’s cut, or a brown center.
Keep cutting this off until you get to a healthy white core.
Remove all of the old foliage as well.
After you've removed the damaged part, cut about 1–2 centimetres (0.39–0.79 in) off of the stem at a time until you reach a white core.
Remove stems that are crossing one another.
If you see branches that are criss-crossing each other, remove the branch that’s reaching inwards.
Removing these will keep them from rubbing up against each other and getting tangled.
Take off branches that are super thin or weak.
Your goal is to keep stems that are strong and thick, so remove ones that seem too thin to support the weight of the plant.
The branch should be at least as thick as a pencil, as well as green and healthy.
If you have lots of branches that seem healthy and strong, aim for clipping off the thinner ones until you have 5-6 main stems.
Directing the Growth Cut each branch at a 45° angle.
When using your pruning shears, instead of creating a flat cut right across the stem, aim for making an angled cut.
This allows water to drain off more easily, preventing water from collecting and causing rot.
A 45° cut also helps prevent pests from sitting on the stems.
Trim stems growing into the center to allow better air flow.
Opening up the center of the plant will let more air and sunlight filter through, benefiting the rest of the plant.
If you see branches that are growing inwards instead of outwards, cut these off.
If the entire branch is growing inwards starting at the base near the roots, cut the entire branch off.
Remove buds that are facing the interior of the plant.
If you see a bud forming that’s facing the middle of the plant instead of growing outwards, clip this off.
You want buds that will grow away from the plant, or even ones that are facing to the side.
Be careful to only clip off the small bud, not the entire stem.
Prune right above an outward-facing bud to encourage the growth.
After you’ve spotted a bud that’s growing out and away from the plant, prune right above the bud.
Clipping too close to the bud might damage it, so aim for cutting roughly 0.25 in (0.64 cm) above the bud.
Pruning this way will encourage your blooms and branches to grow outward, instead of toward the center of the plant.
Don’t forget to cut at an angle with your pruning shears.
Choosing Best Practices Prune the tea roses in the winter or spring, depending on your climate.
If you live in a climate that gets warmer towards the end of the winter, you can prune the tea roses then.
If you live somewhere with cold, longer winters, you'll need to wait until spring.
Once the threat of frost passes, you're ready to prune.
Clean your pruning shears using soap and water.
Pour a dab or two of dish soap onto a sponge or washcloth.
Run the sponge or washcloth under warm water and begin scrubbing down the pruning shears.
Once they're all clean, run them under water to rinse the soap off and dry them thoroughly.
Cleaning your pruning shears (or scissors, if necessary) is important so that you don't spread disease while cutting stems.
Drying your shears super well right after washing them will help prevent rust.
Apply wood glue to the stem after you make a cut.
This helps seal off the cut, preventing disease and insects from getting into the plant and eating it.
You can use a regular wood glue that's water soluble.
Find wood glue from a home improvement or art store.
You can also purchase specialty glues that are designed specifically for pruning roses.
